title: Authors and Citation
text: Muto H (2025). pwranova: Power Analysis Flexible ANOVA Designs Related Tests. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {pwranova: Power Analysis for Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests},   author = {Hiroyuki Muto},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: Power Analysis for Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
title: Power Analysis for Flexible ANOVA Designs and Related Tests
text: R pakcage developed

what: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: function converts Cohen's f partial eta squared (\(\eta_p^2\)) using method described Cohen (1988). Partial eta squared commonly reported effect size index ANOVA.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: f numeric vector Cohen's f values. value must greater equal 0.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: numeric vector partial eta squared values.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: conversion defined : $$\eta_p^2 = \frac{f^2}{1 + f^2}$$

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Convert Cohen's f to Partial Eta Squared — cohensf_to_peta2
code: # Convert a single Cohen's f value cohensf_to_peta2(0.25) #> [1] 0.05882353  # Convert multiple values cohensf_to_peta2(c(0.1, 0.25, 0.4)) #> [1] 0.00990099 0.05882353 0.13793103

what: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: function converts partial eta squared (\(\eta_p^2\)) Cohen's f using method described Cohen (1988). Cohen's f commonly used effect size index power analysis ANOVA.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: peta2 numeric vector partial eta squared values. value must within range 0 1.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: numeric vector Cohen's f values.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: conversion defined : $$f = \sqrt{\eta_p^2 / (1 - \eta_p^2)}$$

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Convert Partial Eta Squared to Cohen's f — peta2_to_cohensf
code: # Convert a single partial eta squared value peta2_to_cohensf(0.06) #> [1] 0.2526456  # Convert multiple values peta2_to_cohensf(c(0.01, 0.06, 0.14)) #> [1] 0.1005038 0.2526456 0.4034733

what: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Computes power, required total sample size, alpha, minimal detectable effect size fixed-effects terms -/within-/mixed-factor ANOVA designs.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
code: pwranova(   nlevels_b = NULL,   nlevels_w = NULL,   n_total = NULL,   cohensf = NULL,   peta2 = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   epsilon = 1,   target = NULL,   max_nfactor = 6,   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: nlevels_b Integer vector. Numbers levels -participant factors. Omit set NULL -participant factor. nlevels_w Integer vector. Numbers levels within-participant factors. Omit set NULL within-participant factor. n_total Integer integer vector. Total sample size(s) across groups. NULL, function solves n_total. cohensf Numeric. Cohen's \(f\) (non-negative). NULL, derived peta2 available. peta2 Numeric \((0,1)\). Partial eta squared. NULL, derived cohensf available. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved . power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved achieve power. epsilon Numeric \((0,1]\). Nonsphericity (Greenhouse–Geisser) parameter applied within-participant terms \(\mathrm{df}_1 \ge 2\). Ignored within-participant factor within factors 2 levels. target Character vector term labels compute (e.g., "B1", "W1", "B1:W1", ...). NULL, terms returned. max_nfactor Integer. Safety cap total number factors. nlim Integer length-2. Search range total n solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: data frame S3 class: "cal_power" power calculated given n_total, alpha, effect size; "cal_n" "cal_ns" n_total solved; "cal_alpha" "cal_alphas" alpha solved; "cal_es" minimal detectable effect sizes solved. Columns include term, df_num, df_denom, n_total, alpha, power, cohensf, peta2, criticalF, ncp, epsilon.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Numerator df adjusted epsilon within terms \(\mathrm{df}_1 \ge 2\). Denominator df follow standard mixed ANOVA formulas, multiplied epsilon within terms. Critical values use central F; power uses noncentral F \(\lambda = f^2 \cdot n_\mathrm{total}\).

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Power Analysis for Between-, Within-, or Mixed-Factor ANOVA — pwranova
code: # One between factor (k=3), one within factor (m=4), compute power pwranova(nlevels_b = 3, nlevels_w = 4, n_total = 60,          cohensf = 0.25, alpha = 0.05, power = NULL, epsilon = 0.8) #>    term df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power cohensf      peta2 criticalF #> 1    B1    2.0    57.00      60  0.05 0.3744311    0.25 0.05882353  3.158843 #> 2    W1    2.4   109.44      60  0.05 0.3572373    0.25 0.05882353  2.893568 #> 3 B1:W1    4.8   218.88      60  0.05 0.2725086    0.25 0.05882353  2.282719 #>    ncp epsilon #> 1 3.75     1.0 #> 2 3.75     0.8 #> 3 3.75     0.8 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # Solve required total N for target power pwranova(nlevels_b = 2, nlevels_w = NULL, n_total = NULL,          peta2 = 0.06, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8) #>   term df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power   cohensf peta2 criticalF #> 1   B1      1      124     126  0.05 0.8034337 0.2526456  0.06   3.91755 #>        ncp epsilon #> 1 8.042553       1 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.

what: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: Computes power, required total sample size, alpha, minimal detectable effect size single planned contrast (1 df) -participants paired/repeated-measures settings.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
code: pwrcontrast(   weight = NULL,   paired = FALSE,   n_total = NULL,   cohensf = NULL,   peta2 = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   power = NULL,   nlim = c(2, 10000) )

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: weight Numeric vector (length \(K \ge 2\)). Contrast weights whose sum must (approximately) zero. paired Logical. FALSE -subjects (default), TRUE paired/repeated-measures. n_total Integer integer vector. Total sample size(s). NULL, function solves n_total. cohensf Numeric (non-negative). Cohen's \(f\). NULL, derived peta2 available. peta2 Numeric \((0,1)\). Partial eta squared. NULL, derived cohensf available. alpha Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, solved . power Numeric \((0,1)\). NULL, computed; n_total NULL, n_total solved achieve power. nlim Integer length-2. Search range total n solving sample size.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: one-row data frame class: "cal_power" power calculated given n_total, alpha, effect size; "cal_n" n_total solved; "cal_alpha" alpha solved; "cal_es" minimal detectable effect sizes solved. Columns: term (always "contrast"), weight (comma-separated string), df_num, df_denom, n_total, alpha, power, cohensf, peta2, criticalF, ncp.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: contrast weights \(w_1, \dots, w_K\) sum zero, numerator df 1. denominator df \(n - K\) -subjects (unpaired) designs \((n - 1)(K - 1)\) paired/repeated-measures designs. Power uses noncentral F \(\lambda = f^2 \cdot n_{\mathrm{total}}\). weight normalized internally; zero-sum condition enforced (numerical tolerance). paired = FALSE, n_total must multiple \(K\). function enforces exactly one n_total, cohensf/peta2, alpha, power NULL.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: Power Analysis for Planned Contrast in Between- or Within-Factor ANOVA — pwrcontrast
code: # Two-group contrast (1, -1), between-subjects: compute power pwrcontrast(weight = c(1, -1), paired = FALSE,             n_total = 40, cohensf = 0.25, alpha = 0.05) #>       term weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha    power cohensf      peta2 #> 1 contrast   1,-1      1       38      40  0.05 0.337939    0.25 0.05882353 #>   criticalF ncp #> 1  4.098172 2.5 #> Power (1 - beta) was calculated based on the total sample size, effect size, and alpha.  # Four-level contrast (e.g., Helmert-like), solve required N for target power pwrcontrast(weight = c(3, -1, -1, -1), paired = FALSE,             n_total = NULL, peta2 = 0.06, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80) #>       term     weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power   cohensf peta2 #> 1 contrast 3,-1,-1,-1      1      124     128  0.05 0.8095375 0.2526456  0.06 #>   criticalF      ncp #> 1   3.91755 8.170213 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.  # Paired contrast across K=3 conditions pwrcontrast(weight = c(1, 0, -1), paired = TRUE,             n_total = NULL, cohensf = 0.2, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.9) #>       term weight df_num df_denom n_total alpha     power cohensf      peta2 #> 1 contrast 1,0,-1      1      526     264  0.05 0.9003788     0.2 0.03846154 #>   criticalF   ncp #> 1  3.859198 10.56 #> The required total sample size was calculated based on the effect size, alpha, and power. #> Note: 'power' indicates the achieved power rather than the target power.

title: pwranova 0.0.0.9000
